examples.en: You should be aware that you're also a member of society.
examples.ja: もう少し社会人としての自覚を持った方がいいよ。

examples.en: My husband told me I lack an awareness for maternal responsibilities and that made me super upset.
examples.ja: 夫から、母親としての自覚が無いって言われて、めっちゃムカついたんです。

examples.en: I've heard that most people who engage in moral harassment are completely unaware of it, but what made you realize you were committing moral harassment, Yamamoto-san?
examples.ja: モラハラは、自分では全く自覚がない人がほとんどだと聞いたんですが、山本さんがご自身のモラハラを自覚された時は、きっかけって何かありましたか？

meaning_mnemonic:
What does <kanji>self</kanji> and <kanji>awake</kanji> mean in combination? This refers to <vocabulary>self-awareness</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>consciousness</vocabulary> of yourself, or a <vocabulary>realization</vocabulary>.

Wondering about the difference between 意識 and 自覚? 意識 refers to a general state of awareness or consciousness, while 自覚 specifically relates to self-awareness. It implies clearly recognizing one's own actions, abilities, or circumstances, and is often used in contexts relating to personal growth.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I started working part-time as a dishwasher in a restaurant.
examples.ja: レストランで皿洗いのバイトを始めました。

examples.en: I saw on TV that there is a ramen shop where you can pay for your meal by washing dishes, is this true?
examples.ja: 食事代は皿洗いでOKなラーメン屋さんがあるってテレビで見たんですけど、本当ですか？

examples.en: While my husband is lying on the living room sofa, I feel really sad doing the piled-up dishes, stealing sideways glances at him.
examples.ja: リビングのソファで横になっている夫を横目に、たまりにたまったお皿の皿洗いをしているとき、とても悲しくなります。

meaning_mnemonic: You know the word 皿 (plate) and the word 洗う (to wash), right? You can probably guess dish washing is happening here, but this is a noun, so it's the idea of <vocabulary>dishwashing</vocabulary>, AKA <vocabulary>doing dishes</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>washing dishes</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The readings are the individual vocab words (you can tell because there's a bit of hiragana stuck on there). It's the reading for 皿 and 洗う combined.

examples.en: I'm troubled when you say things like that to me.
examples.ja: そんなこと僕に言われても困るよ。

examples.en: I forgot my money at home and now I'm in big trouble.
examples.ja: お金を家に忘れてきてしまって、今めっちゃ困っています。

examples.en: I listened to wheelchair users and compiled their concerns.
examples.ja: 車イスユーザーの方にお話を聞いて、困りごとをまとめました。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>distressed</kanji> and <kanji>troubled</kanji>. The verb versions of those are <vocabulary>to be distressed</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to be troubled</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: If someone seems <vocabulary>to be distressed</vocabulary> maybe someone they know is in a <reading>coma</reading> (こま). Not too many things are more distressing and troubling than that.

examples.en: I never thought I'd see the day that the Japanese era name was changed to WaniKani.
examples.ja: まさか日本の年号がワニカニに改まる日が来るなんて！

examples.en: Don’t be so formal! The president of our company is very friendly.
examples.ja: そう改まるなよ。うちの社長は、とても気さくなんだから。

examples.en: When I looked up at the sky from the top of that mountain, I felt my heart become solemn.
examples.ja: その山の上で空を見上げると、心が改まるような気持ちになりました。

examples.en: I don't see his bad habits changing anytime soon.
examples.ja: アイツの悪いクセがすぐに改まるとは思えないよ。

examples.en: After hearing everyone's stories, my thoughts have changed.
examples.ja: 皆さんのお話を聞いて、考えが改まりました。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.

The kanji itself means <kanji>renew</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to be renewed</vocabulary>. Like most verbs ending in まる, this is an intransitive verb, meaning it doesn't take a direct object. Something renews or gets renewed, or something changes. See? No direct object.

Although it's not often translated as "renew," 改まる implies a kind of renewal in the changes it's used to describe — whether it's the revision of regulations or the old year changing over to a new one. It can also be used for personal improvements, or describe a shift to a more formal demeanor in social situations.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You might remember this reading from the transitive verb 改める, but here's a mnemonic just in case: 

<vocabulary>To be renewed</vocabulary> means to be changed into something <reading>新た</reading> (あらた). Out with the old, in with the 新た, right? Picture yourself in a situation where there's been a lot of change. Try to remember how it feels when everything is 新た. Are you nervous, excited, or do you usually move on without noticing?

examples.en: Water and oil, do they mix? Or don't they?
examples.ja: 水と油って、混ざるんだっけ？混ざらないんだっけ？

examples.en: Yellow mixed with blue and red, resulting in a brownish color.
examples.ja: 黄色に青色と赤色が混ざって、にじんで茶色っぽくなってしまいました。

examples.en: I felt really sad and lonely because I couldn't contribute to the conversation at all.
examples.ja: みんなの会話に混ざることができなくてとても悲しかったし、さみしかったよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>mix</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to get mixed</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be mixed</vocabulary>. 

混ざる is used to talk about something getting mixed, without focusing on who did the mixing. You can remember this because the <reading>Tzar</reading> (ざる) of Russia presided over lots of things getting mixed together — peoples, languages, religions. The Tzar's empire was a big melting pot where all kinds of things got mixed together.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

Who always wants things <vocabulary>to get mixed</vocabulary> well? Your <reading>ma</reading> (ま)! Whether it's her soup or the colors she paints with, everything she touches ends up getting mixed well and coming together nicely.

examples.en: We caught more than enough fish ice fishing, so please take some if you'd like.
examples.ja: 穴づりでつった魚が余っているので、良かったら少しいかがですか？

examples.en: From the way they live, they seem to have quite an excess of money, don't you think?
examples.ja: くらしぶりからして、あの夫妻、相当お金が余ってそうだと思いませんか。

examples.en: There is an abundance of apples in our orchard.
examples.ja: 私達の果樹園にはあり余るほどの林檎があります。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>surplus</kanji> so the verb version would be <vocabulary>to be in surplus</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to remain left over</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to be in excess</vocabulary>. Too much!
reading_mnemonic: Something you don't want <vocabulary>to be in surplus</vocabulary> is <reading>armor</reading> (あま). Armor is heavy and it takes up a lot of space, so you need maybe one set at most. If you have enough for it <vocabulary>to remain left over</vocabulary> when you go off to battle, well, you probably have too much.

examples.en: This is one too many chairs, isn't it?
examples.ja: このイス、一つ余計だったね。

examples.en: You know that, right? Don't say anything unnecessary, okay?
examples.ja: 分かってるよね？余計なことはゼッタイに言わないでね！

examples.en: My son told me I was meddling too much, and that just made me even more irritated.
examples.ja: 息子から「余計なお世話だ」って言われて、余計にイライラしちゃったんですよね。

meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>surplus</kanji> is <kanji>measure</kanji>d and it's all <vocabulary>unneeded</vocabulary>. Yeah, it's definitely <vocabulary>more than needed</vocabulary>. Maybe we should get rid of all this surplus?

余計 usually carries a negative connotation, meaning there's <vocabulary>too much</vocabulary> of something, or it's not needed and could be left out. It could be too many things, or unnecessary words or actions it would be better not to say or do.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: This is my personal opinion.
examples.ja: これは私個人の意見です。

examples.en: Personally, I am against it.
examples.ja: 個人的には反対です。

examples.en: I went to a small, stylish cafe that is independently run by a friend.
examples.ja: 友達が個人でやってる、こじんまりとしたオシャレカフェに行ってきました。

meaning_mnemonic: In terms of an <kanji>individual</kanji> <kanji>person</kanji>... well, that's <vocabulary>personal</vocabulary>, and depends on the <vocabulary>individual</vocabulary>. Whatever it is, an individual person has personal tastes, so make sure to think of that.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Alright, alright. Just one, okay?
examples.ja: しょうがないなぁ。一個だけだよ？

examples.en: What? These strawberries are 1,500 yen each!
examples.ja: え、このイチゴ、一個千五百円だって！

examples.en: There's one cream puff for each person, so there's no need to fight over them.
examples.ja: シュークリーム、ちゃんと一人一個ずつあるから、取り合わなくていいよ。

meaning_mnemonic: The counter 個, which means <kanji>individual</kanji> on its own, refers to "an individual thing." This is usually a small thing, so it's used to count small things. This word here talks about <kanji>one</kanji> <kanji>individual</kanji>. A better way to translate that would be to call it <vocabulary>one small thing</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The いち gets shortened, but I bet you knew that already.

examples.en: I reserved a private room at a cafe and enjoyed a leisurely chat with my friends.
examples.ja: カフェで個室を予約して、友達とゆっくりおしゃべりを楽しみました。

examples.en: Toilets in individual stalls sometimes have small cameras installed, so be careful!

examples.en: When I went to the gym, luckily the private training area was available.

meaning_mnemonic: An <kanji>individual</kanji> <kanji>room</kanji> just for you is your own <vocabulary>private room</vocabulary>. How nice!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I put three milks and three syrup cups in my coffee.
examples.ja: コーヒーにはミルクとシロップを三個ずつ入れます。

examples.en: I bought a box of soap that comes with three bars.
examples.ja: 三個入りの石けんを一箱買いました。

examples.en: I feel really sick now after eating three cheeseburgers and thirty-three nuggets.
examples.ja: チーズバーガー三個の他に、ナゲットを三十三個も食べたので、今とても気持ちが悪い。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Three</kanji> <kanji>individual</kanji>s is <vocabulary>three small things</vocabulary>. The kanji 個 can be used to count small objects, just like this! Try other numbers as well.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Man, this Bowser is too strong. If you know how to defeat him, please tell me!

examples.en: The stack of books collapsed like dominoes when I knocked over one.
examples.ja: その本の山は、一つ倒すとドミノ倒しのように全部くずれ落ちてきてしまいました。

examples.en: While helping to cut down trees in the mountains, I was hit by a chainsaw on the neck and got seriously injured.
examples.ja: 山で木を切り倒す手伝いをしていた時、チェーンソーが首に当たって、大ケガをしたんです。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.

The kanji itself means <kanji>overthrow</kanji> or <kanji>collapse</kanji>, and this is a transitive verb (like most verbs ending in す) related to those actions. It means <vocabulary>to knock over</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to bring down</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to defeat</vocabulary>.

It can be used to talk about physically knocking something over, as well as bringing something or someone down, like a government, or defeating someone, like an enemy.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

If you want to knock over something, you'll have to go to <reading>tow</reading>n (たお) on it. You'll never be able to knock down anything if all your efforts are perfunctory. You really gotta go to town on that thing!

examples.en: You've taken on such a difficult job!
examples.ja: こりゃまた面倒な仕事を引き受けたもんだね。

examples.en: I find it tiresome to respond to nasty comments, so I just ignore and block them.
examples.ja: クソリプは、言い返すのも面倒だし、シカトしてブロックするようにしています。

examples.en: I've caused our president various troubles, and yet he's always taken care of me, so I'm filled with gratitude.

meaning_mnemonic: When you're looking straight into the <kanji>face</kanji> of a <kanji>collapse</kanji> it means <vocabulary>trouble</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>difficulty</vocabulary> coming soon.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The とう goes to どう, though. Agh, what a <vocabulary>面倒</vocabulary>.

examples.en: Father, I saw the news about your company's bankruptcy!

meaning_mnemonic: If someone <kanji>overthrow</kanji>s your <kanji>property</kanji>, it'll end in <vocabulary>bankruptcy</vocabulary>. Without property you're sure to <vocabulary>go bankrupt</vocabulary>, unfortunately.

examples.en: That apartment still doesn’t have any tenants because it’s rumored to be haunted.

meaning_mnemonic:
Remember how 手 can mean "doer" in some words? So here, you have <kanji>borrow</kanji> <kanji>doer</kanji>, or more simply <vocabulary>borrower</vocabulary>.

This word is often used to specifically refer to borrowers in contrast to lenders.
reading_mnemonic: You'll want to know the words 借りる and 手 to be able to read this one. Combine them to know the reading.

examples.en: Wow, this wall is very thick, isn't it?

examples.en: This glove has thick memory foam padding, so it seems perfect for long rides!

meaning_mnemonic:
This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>thick</kanji>? Also <vocabulary>thick</vocabulary>.

This is a relatively formal word that is generally used in writing.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. No <vocabulary>thick</vocabulary> books needed to understand this reading, yeah?

examples.ja: 低血圧だから朝起きられなくて困っているんです。今日は血圧をはかってもらったら、上が85で下が30でした。コウイチ先生、何とかしてもらえませんか？

meaning_mnemonic: Check the <kanji>pressure</kanji> of your <kanji>blood</kanji>. It's your <vocabulary>blood pressure</vocabulary>.

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>bad</kanji> <kanji>dream</kanji> is also known as a <vocabulary>nightmare</vocabulary>. Ah! Noooooo!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Wow, it's like a dream come true!
examples.ja: うわー、夢みたい！

examples.en: My dream is to go and work in Japan.
examples.ja: 私の夢は日本に行って、日本で働くことです。

examples.en: Yesterday, I had a dream that Koichi was giving me a shiatsu massage.
examples.ja: 昨日、コウイチに指圧をしてもらっている夢を見たんだ。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You're having this crazy <vocabulary>dream</vocabulary>. The dream allows you to do anything you want. Every time you ask "hey, can I do this?" The answer is always "<reading>you may</reading>" (ゆめ). Think of some things you'd want to do if you could do anything. Ask permission and get this answer in your imagination.

examples.en: In this job, it's necessary to wear a helmet for safety.
examples.ja: この仕事では、安全のためにヘルメットを被る必要があります。

examples.en: In this photo, the one wearing the New York Yankees cap is my brother.
examples.ja: この写真でニューヨーク・ヤンキースのキャップを被ってるのが私の弟です。

examples.en: My child always wears a mask of innocence in front of non-family members.
examples.ja: うちの子は、他人の前ではいつも猫を被ります。

examples.en: I saw a man wearing pantyhose over his head running out of the bank with money. I'm glad our timing for entering the bank didn't coincide!
examples.ja: ストッキングを被った男が銀行からお金を持って走って出ていくのを見ました。銀行に入るタイミングが被らなくて良かった！

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji means <kanji>cover</kanji>, so the verb version means <vocabulary>to put on</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to wear</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to cover oneself with</vocabulary>.

被る is used when you wear things that cover your head or face, like hats, helmets, and masks, or when cover yourself with something, like pulling a blanket over yourself. Figuratively, it can also refer to overlapping events — think of it like one event "covering" another on a timeline.

Since the kanji's other meaning is <kanji>incur</kanji>, 被る can also mean taking on a burden or blame — incurring responsibility, in other words.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Every time you go <vocabulary>to put on</vocabulary> your hat, you yell "<reading>KABOO</reading>M (かぶ)!" Why? Because your hat is da bomb. Go ahead, try it: put on your super cool hat while shouting out "KABOOM!" Is everyone looking at you now? Did they realize the hat you're wearing is da bomb?

examples.en: Today I had a date with my wife.
examples.ja: 今日は妻とデートでした。

examples.en: I wonder if my ex-wife will return the car I gave her as a present.
examples.ja: 元妻にプレゼントした車、返してくれないかな？

examples.en: My wife puts Vaseline on her nostrils every morning before going to work.
examples.ja: 僕の妻は毎朝会社に行く前に鼻の穴にワセリンをぬります。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This is used to refer to your own wife, though, for the most part.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: Your <kanji>wife</kanji> does everything for you. She feeds you, she bathes you, she cleans up after you and even wipes your butt when you poop. Really, she is doing <reading>too mu</reading>ch (つま), and you should stop being a baby.

examples.en: That married couple look exactly alike.
examples.ja: あの夫妻は顔がそっくりです。

examples.en: Mr. and Mrs. Otani and Mr. and Mrs. Darvish also attended that BBQ.
examples.ja: そのBBQには、大谷夫妻やダルビッシュ夫妻も参加していました。

examples.en: A doctor couple I know advised me to avoid that particular medication.
examples.ja: 知人のお医者さん夫妻から、あの薬だけはやめといた方がいいって止められたんです。

meaning_mnemonic: You have a <kanji>husband</kanji> and a <kanji>wife</kanji>. Combine them together and they're <vocabulary>husband and wife</vocabulary>, or a <vocabulary>married couple</vocabulary>. This can also be added to a name to mean <vocabulary>Mr. and Mrs.</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Going out to eat with another woman when you have a wife and kids is not okay.
examples.ja: 妻子がいるのに、他の女性と二人でご飯に行くのはダメでしょ。

examples.en: All the male employees in our company are married and have children.
examples.ja: うちの会社の男性社員は全員妻子持ちです。

examples.en: She was crying, saying she had fallen in love with a married man with kids, but I told her firmly, "If you have time to cry, then hurry up and break up."
examples.ja: あの子、妻子のある人を好きになってしまったって言って泣いてたんだけど、泣いてるヒマがあるならさっさと別れなよって強く言っちゃった。

meaning_mnemonic: You have your <kanji>wife</kanji> and you have your <kanji>child</kanji>. These are your <vocabulary>wife and kids</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Even if polygamy were to be accepted, without financial stability, it's unlikely that we could halt the declining birthrate, right?
examples.ja: たとえ一夫多妻がOKになっても、お金がなければ少子化は止められないでしょ。

examples.en: Oh, are there people in Japan who practice polygamy?
examples.ja: え、日本で一夫多妻をしてる人達もいるんですか！？

examples.en: Chimera anglerfish, Japanese tree frogs, and honey bees, for example, have a mating system opposite to polygyny, called polyandry.
examples.ja: チョウチンアンコウやモリアオガエル、ミツバチなんかは一夫多妻の反対で、一妻多夫なんですよ。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>One</kanji> <kanji>husband</kanji>, <kanji>many</kanji> <kanji>wives</kanji>. Sounds a bit sketchy. This is <vocabulary>polygamy</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just note that the 一 gets changed to いっ and the 夫 gets changed to ぷ from ふう for some reason. You can imagine that this is because when you are the type that has many wives, you're probably the type who makes them clean up your <reading>poo</reading> for you as well.

examples.en: I would hate to do that for sure.
examples.ja: それはゼッタイ嫌です。

examples.en: My girlfriend's annoying habit is probably when she makes mashed potatoes by putting hot water in potato chips.
examples.ja: 僕の彼女の嫌なところは、ポテトチップスにお湯を入れてマッシュポテトを作るとこかな。

examples.en: If you don't like your job, why don't you quit? It's not good for you to do something you don't want to do.
examples.ja: 仕事が嫌なら、やめたら？嫌なことを嫌々するのは体に良くないよ。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. The vocab has the added meanings of <vocabulary>eww</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>gross</vocabulary>, and even <vocabulary>reluctant</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for this word is pretty weird. It's different than the 嫌い word you will see in this level too. It is いや, so when you think of something you dislike, just think "<reading>iyah</reading> (いや), I dislike it." Also, think about that <vocabulary>eww</vocabulary> feeling it gives you when you think of the thing you dislike most.

examples.en: I hate green peppers.
examples.ja: 私はピーマンが嫌いです。

examples.en: I don't have anyone I don't like.
examples.ja: 僕には嫌いな人はいません。

examples.en: I'm sorry for everything. I know you might think I'm a jerk, but please don't hate me if you can.
examples.ja: 色々とごめんね。俺のこと、嫌なやつと思ってるかもしれないけど、できれば嫌いにならないでほしいな。

meaning_mnemonic:
You know that 嫌 means <kanji>dislike</kanji> and this vocab word means the same thing: <vocabulary>dislike</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>hate</vocabulary>!

Though this word is an adjective in Japanese, it usually makes sense to translate it as a verb in English, because of the difference in sentence structure. However, a more literal translation would be <vocabulary>dislikable</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>detestable</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Of all the things out there to <vocabulary>dislike</vocabulary> the thing I dislike the most is the <reading>killer</reading> (きら) of people. People should never kill people.

examples.en: What kind of mood is mom in today?
examples.ja: 今日のお母さんの機嫌はどう？

examples.en: Grandpa is in a really good mood! What happened?
examples.ja: おじいちゃん、めっちゃ機嫌いいね！どうしちゃったの？

examples.en: My father has been in a bad mood since this morning. Apparently, something had happened at work.
examples.ja: 父は朝から機嫌が悪い。どうやら仕事で何かあったようだ。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Machine</kanji>s <kanji>dislike</kanji> everything. Their <vocabulary>mood</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>temper</vocabulary>, is very sour. What about your mood?
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. けん gets changed to げん, though, so don't let that ruin your <vocabulary>mood</vocabulary>.

examples.en: Our suspicion that Viet is a yakuza cannot be wiped away.
examples.ja: ビエトがヤクザだという嫌疑がぬぐえません。

examples.en: That politician is under suspicion of being involved in human trafficking.
examples.ja: あの政治家は人身売買に関わっていた嫌疑をかけられています。

examples.en: It seems like they were deemed "not sufficiently suspicious", huh?
examples.ja: どうやら「嫌疑不十分」とされたみたいだね。

meaning_mnemonic: I <kanji>dislike</kanji> him and I have <kanji>doubt</kanji>s about him. I therefore have much <vocabulary>suspicion</vocabulary> against him as well.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I left a message on the answering machine.
examples.ja: 留守番電話にメッセージを残しました。

examples.en: I've been calling the Tofugu office over and over again, but I always get the answering machine.
examples.ja: トーフグのオフィスに何度も何度も電話をしていますが、いつも留守番電話なんです。

examples.en: On my answering machine, I got a message from Koichi saying he's flying to Hawaii tomorrow.
examples.ja: 留守番電話にコウイチから明日飛行機でハワイに行くというメッセージが入っていました。

meaning_mnemonic: You hopefully know that this has something to do with <vocabulary>housesitting</vocabulary> (留守番). So, a <vocabulary>telephone</vocabulary> (電話) that does housesitting for you is what? It's your <vocabulary>answering machine</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>voicemail</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I believe smoking while walking is pollution.
examples.ja: 私は歩きタバコは公害だと思っています。

examples.en: In Japan, pollution became a huge societal problem between 1950 and 1960.
examples.ja: 日本では1950~1960年代にかけて、公害が大きな社会問題になりました。

examples.en: "Cadmium" is known to have caused one of the four major pollution-related diseases called "Itai-Itai disease."
examples.ja: 「カドミウム」は、四大公害病のひとつ「イタイイタイ病」を引き起こす原因となったことで知られています。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Public</kanji> <kanji>damage</kanji> is something that affects everyone, the whole public. What is in the air and gets into everything no matter where you are? How about <vocabulary>pollution</vocabulary>?
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: It seems that my hometown is in serious trouble due to flooding.
examples.ja: 地元が水害で大変なことになっているようだ。

examples.en: I grew up on a flood-prone island.
examples.ja: 私は、水害の起きやすい島で育ちました。

examples.en: The flood left 5,000 cats homeless.
examples.ja: その水害で、5,000匹の猫が家を失いました。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Water</kanji> <kanji>damage</kanji> is so bad they call it <vocabulary>water damage</vocabulary>. Doesn't get any clearer than this.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I wonder if silicone, which has been used in various processed foods lately, is really harmless. It's even used in coffee.
examples.ja: 最近、色んな加工食品に使われているシリコーンって、本当に無害なのかな？コーヒーにも入ってるんだけど。

examples.en: That guy, with such a harmless-looking face, engaging in sexual harassment... It's unbelievable.
examples.ja: アイツ、あんな無害そうな顔してセクハラをするなんて、信じられないよ。

examples.en: As an Asian living in America, I often feel like I'm just overlooked as a harmless extra unless I actively assert my presence.
examples.ja: 私はアメリカに住むアジア人ですが、自ら存在をアピールしないと、ただの無害なモブとしてスルーされるように感じることは多々あります。

meaning_mnemonic: Psh, that guy's <kanji>damage</kanji> is <kanji>nothing</kanji>. He's what I'd call "mostly <vocabulary>harmless</vocabulary>."
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I got a wart on my buttocks.
examples.ja: お尻にイボができました。

examples.en: When I go to high places, my butt itches.
examples.ja: 高いところに行くと、お尻がかゆくなるんです。

examples.en: This is an exercise for the inner muscles of the buttocks.
examples.ja: これはお尻のインナーマッスルのエクササイズです。

meaning_mnemonic: The お is just there to be nice to your butt. This word simply means <vocabulary>butt</vocabulary> (or any other word for it, like <vocabulary>buttocks</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>bottom</vocabulary>).
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: Bows and arrows are used in this Ainu dance.
examples.ja: このアイヌのダンスでは弓矢が使われます。

examples.en: In this game, I always choose to play with a bow and arrow.
examples.ja: このゲームでは、いつも弓矢を選んでプレイします。

examples.en: I made bamboo bows and arrows in the mountains with my father during summer vacation.
examples.ja: 夏休みに父と山で竹の弓矢を作りました。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>bow</kanji> and an <kanji>arrow</kanji>. Put them together and you have a <vocabulary>bow and arrow</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the vocab readings, 弓 and 矢, put together. This is probably because this word is like two separate words put together, thus the "and" in the middle of the English translation.

examples.en: I forget things a lot.
examples.ja: 私は忘れ物が多い。

examples.en: Isn't this something someone forgot?
examples.ja: これ、誰かの忘れ物じゃない？

examples.en: I feel like I forgot something today, but I just can’t remember what it is.
examples.ja: 今日何か忘れ物をしたような気がするんだけど、それが何だったかをどうしても思い出せないんだよな。

meaning_mnemonic:
Remember how 忘れる is "to forget"? Well, a <kanji>thing</kanji> you've forgotten is a <vocabulary>forgotten item</vocabulary>.

忘れ物 is a casual way to refer to something left behind accidentally, like an umbrella you forgot about and left on the train.
reading_mnemonic: You didn't learn this reading with the kanji 忘, but you did learn it with the vocabulary 忘れる. What was that reading again? You can't remember! It's become a <vocabulary>forgotten item</vocabulary> in some dusty corner of your brain. And really, forgetting how to read 忘? That's <reading>worse</reading> (わす) than leaving your umbrella or keys behind! Come on! Try to hold onto the reading this time — you'll only be making things worse if you don't.

examples.en: What kind of machine is that?
examples.ja: それはなんの機械ですか？

examples.en: Today the machine is not working very smoothly.
examples.ja: 今日は機械の調子があんまり良くないんだよね。

examples.en: Koichi bought a batting cage machine for the office
examples.ja: コウイチは会社用にバッティングセンターの機械を買いました。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>machine</kanji> <kanji>contraption</kanji> is just a <vocabulary>machine</vocabulary>
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I've already booked the airplane tickets.
examples.ja: 飛行機のチケット、もう取っちゃったんだよね。

examples.en: I dislike airplanes, so I would never be able to go to Japan.
examples.ja: 私は飛行機が苦手なので、一生日本に行けることはないでしょう。

examples.en: When I was seated next to Koichi on the plane, I was so surprised that I thought my eyeballs would pop out.
examples.ja: 飛行機でコウイチのとなりの席になった時、ビックリして目玉が飛び出るかと思いました。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>fly</kanji> and <kanji>go</kanji> <kanji>machine</kanji> is some machine you get into that flies and goes places. It's an <vocabulary>airplane</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Japan is currently facing a crisis that threatens its national survival.
examples.ja: 日本は今、国家存亡の危機にあります。

examples.en: Maybe you should have a bit more sense of urgency.
examples.ja: もうちょっと危機感もった方がいいんじゃない？

examples.en: World War III will lead to a crisis of civilization.
examples.ja: 第三次世界大戦は文明の危機につながります。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>dangerous</kanji> <kanji>machine</kanji> is walking through your town, destroying everything. This is a huge <vocabulary>crisis</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: This amulet will surely protect you from disaster.
examples.ja: このお守りが、きっとあなたを災いから守ってくれるでしょう。

examples.en: That doll brought a lot of misfortune to this village.
examples.ja: その人形が、この村に多くの災いをもたらしたんです。

examples.en: The mouth is the source of calamity.
examples.ja: 口は災いの元だよ。

meaning_mnemonic: This is the noun form of <kanji>disaster</kanji>, so it means <vocabulary>disaster</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>misfortune</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

Think about how, the last time <vocabulary>disaster</vocabulary> struck, it <reading>was a wh</reading>ile (わざわ) before things got back to normal.

Be careful of the い on the end, it can be tricky and make you think it's an adjective when it's a noun.

examples.en: There is nothing scarier than natural disasters.
examples.ja: 自然災害ほどおそろしいものはありません。

examples.en: There is even the possibility that a disaster could occur during your trip.
examples.ja: 旅行中に災害が起こる可能性だってあります。

examples.en: Today I'm going to share with you a life hack that will come in handy during disasters and camping.
examples.ja: 今日は災害やキャンプの時に便利なライフハックをお教えします。

examples.en: It can't be helped, but unless the disaster hits where they live, people just end up considering it someone else's problem. There are lots of things you just don't understand unless they affect you.
examples.ja: しょうがないけど、自分が住んでいる場所で災害が起きないと、結局みんな他人事なんだよ。当事者にならないと、分からないことっていっぱいあるからさ。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>disaster</kanji> that does <kanji>damage</kanji>. Usually these are <vocabulary>natural disaster</vocabulary>s, though they could also just be regular <vocabulary>disaster</vocabulary>s as well.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I heard that a fire broke out in that building at dawn.
examples.ja: 明け方、あのビルで火災が発生したそうです。

examples.en: I heard there was a fire at a nuclear power plant, is it true?
examples.ja: 原子力発電所で火災が起きたと聞いたんですが、本当ですか？

examples.en: My father was unconscious for a long time after the fire in his office, but he finally woke up today!
examples.ja: 私の父はオフィスの火災でずっと意識不明でしたが、今日ついに目を覚ましました！

meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>fire</kanji> <kanji>disaster</kanji> is a <vocabulary>fire disaster</vocabulary>, or a <vocabulary>conflagration</vocabulary>.

火災 is a more formal version of 火事. It usually refers to a serious and significant fire that causes extensive damage or loss of life.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: That was a heck of a misfortune, huh?
examples.ja: それはとんだ災難でしたね。

examples.en: That was a tough break earlier. That teacher's always on everyone's case, so you'd do best not to let it get to you.
examples.ja: さっきは災難だったね。あの先生、みんなにうるさいからさ、気にしない方がいいよ。

examples.en: To think I'd come down with the flu during my precious spring break. What a disaster.
examples.ja: せっかくの春休みなのに、インフルになるとは。災難すぎる。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>disaster</kanji> that is <kanji>difficult</kanji> is particularly difficult, making it more of a <vocabulary>misfortune</vocabulary>. Obviously a disaster that wasn't difficult wouldn't really be that bad, so a difficult one gets the "misfortune" or <vocabulary>calamity</vocabulary> label.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I still can't forget the trauma I experienced from the day of the earthquake disaster.
examples.ja: 震災にあった日のことが、今でも忘れられないトラウマになっています。

examples.en: A teacher at my school did not return home after the earthquake.
examples.ja: 私の学校の先生は震災で帰らぬ人となりました。

examples.en: The earthquake left the ground full of holes. Here, three months after the earthquake, the ground is still covered with cracks.
examples.ja: 震災で、地面が穴ぼこだらけになってしまいました。ここでは、震災から三ヶ月たった今でも、地面にヒビが入ったままです。

meaning_mnemonic: An <kanji>earthquake</kanji> <kanji>disaster</kanji> is just that, an <vocabulary>earthquake disaster</vocabulary>. These are no good.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I thought it smelled smoky, turns out there was a fire in the neighborhood.
examples.ja: なんか煙いと思ったら、近所で火事が起きてたらしい。

examples.en: The smoky fireworks made me cough.
examples.ja: 花火が煙くて、むせてしまいました。

examples.en: It’s so smoky! When the heck are you going to quit smoking? This really smells awful.
examples.ja: 煙いなあ！一体いつになったらタバコやめるんだよ？本当に臭いんだけど。

meaning_mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>smoke</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>smoky</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You sort of did learn this reading with the vocabulary word 煙, but this one is just different enough where we thought we should make a mnemonic for this one: 

All this <vocabulary>smoki</vocabulary>ness is from a terrible <reading>chem</reading>ical (けむ) spill that happened nearby. It was acid, so it burned everything up real good, causing the air to get pretty smoky.

examples.en: Oops, embarrassing! I can't believe I made such a basic mistake!
examples.ja: うわっ、はずかしい！こんな初歩的なミスを犯すとは！

examples.en: Unless we create and adhere to protocols rigorously, the era of AI committing murder might be upon us.
examples.ja: きちんとプロトコルを作ってみんなで守らないと、AIが殺人を犯す時代がやってくるかもしれません。

examples.en: "The ignorance of the law is no excuse" means that even if someone did something without knowing the law, it cannot be claimed that they had no intention to commit a crime.
examples.ja: 「法の不知は許さず」とは、たとえ法を知らずにやってしまったことだとしても、罪を犯す意思がなかったとすることにはできないというものです。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>crime</kanji> and the verb vocab version can mean <vocabulary>to commit a crime</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to make a mistake</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to rape</vocabulary>, depending on the context.
reading_mnemonic: You go <vocabulary>to commit a crime</vocabulary>. How did it go, you think? Well, I thought it went <reading>oka</reading>y (おか). Imagine yourself committing a crime and it going just okay. Not great, not bad... meh. Okay.

examples.en: The culprit who ate the cookies turned out to be Dad.
examples.ja: クッキー食べた犯人、お父さんだった。

examples.en: I heard they haven't caught the culprit yet.
examples.ja: まだ犯人つかまってないらしいよ。

examples.en: The criminal learned the hard way that speaking carelessly can bring disaster.
examples.ja: その犯人は、口は災いの元だということを思い知った。

meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>crime</kanji>  <kanji>person</kanji> is a <vocabulary>culprit</vocabulary>, or a <vocabulary>criminal</vocabulary>.

Just note that 犯人 is mostly used to talk about the culprit of a specific crime, not criminals in general.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: They say the accomplice is most likely out of the country.
examples.ja: 共犯者は国外にいる可能性が高いそうだ。

examples.en: My accomplice's son was born in January of the year before last.
examples.ja: 共犯者の息子は、一昨年の一月に生まれました。

examples.en: The accomplice was indeed like a bug that flew into the fire in summer.
examples.ja: あの共犯者は、まさに飛んで火にいる夏の虫だったな。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Someone</kanji> who does <kanji>crime</kanji> <kanji>together</kanji> with you is your <vocabulary>accomplice</vocabulary> in crime. It's best to "take care of" these before the coppers get to them.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Do you know how likely it is to win the lottery?
examples.ja: 宝くじに当たる確率がどのくらいか知っていますか？

examples.en: It feels like I have curry on Fridays with a high probability.
examples.ja: なんか金曜日は高確率でカレーを食べてる気がする。

examples.en: I feel like the chances of dating Midori-chan are fifty-fifty, but do you think they're even lower?
examples.ja: ミドリちゃんと付き合える確率、自分では五分五分かなって思ってるんだけど、もっと低いと思う？

meaning_mnemonic: You're <kanji>certain</kanji> there is this <kanji>percent</kanji> chance it will happen? You know that this is the <vocabulary>probability</vocabulary>?
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: The male to female ratio in our company is 5:2.
examples.ja: うちの会社の男女比率は、5:2です。

examples.en: Approximately what percentage of GDP is that?
examples.ja: それってGDP比率の何パーセントぐらいですか？

examples.en: When you are trying to learn something, you should consider the ratio of input to output.
examples.ja: 何かを学ぼうとするときは、インプットとアウトプットの比率を考えながら学ぶといいですよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
You <kanji>compare</kanji> the <kanji>percentage</kanji>, figuring out the <vocabulary>ratio</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>proportion</vocabulary> of one thing to another. This can also be expressed as a <vocabulary>percentage</vocabulary>!

比率 usually shows up in cases where you compare two numbers with each other, like the number of male and female students in a classroom.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: That is certainly true.
examples.ja: それは確かにそうですね。

examples.en: He is certainly a good leader. But the problem is that sometimes his language is too harsh.
examples.ja: 彼は確かにリーダーに向いていると思います。でも、時々言葉がきついのがネックです。

examples.en: I'm certain I saw Koichi fly about one hundred meters with my own eyes.
examples.ja: コウイチが百メートルほど飛ぶのを、この目で確かに見ました。

meaning_mnemonic: This is an adverb, but it has the same meaning (basically) as the kanji. It means <vocabulary>certainly</vocabulary>, and it can also mean <vocabulary>surely</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for this one is <vocabulary>certainly</vocabulary> weird. To remember the reading for this word, just think how you're certain that if you s<reading>tash</reading> (たし) the treasure, nobody will find it here.

examples.en: I did the calculations on the computer, so they are accurate.
examples.ja: コンピュータで計算したので、正確ですよ。

examples.en: That reporter's reporting is always very accurate.
examples.ja: その記者の報道はいつもとても正確です。

examples.en: Koichi doesn't know the accurate number of WaniKani users.
examples.ja: コウイチはワニカニの正確なユーザー数を知りません。

meaning_mnemonic: It is <kanji>correct</kanji> and you're <kanji>certain</kanji> of it. When you've done this much checking and you're this sure, your measurements must be very <vocabulary>accurate</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>precise</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: The backroom of the grocery store is off-limits.
examples.ja: スーパーのバックヤードは立入禁止です。

examples.en: This door says Authorized Personnel Only.
examples.ja: このドアには、関係者以外立入禁止って書かれているよ。

examples.en: When people hear that something is off-limits, they want to go in, don't they?
examples.ja: 立入禁止って聞くと入りたくなっちゃうのが人間でしょ？

meaning_mnemonic:
<kanji>Stand</kanji>ing and <kanji>enter</kanji>ing are both 禁止 (prohibited). If you see this sign, it's essentially saying <vocabulary>do not enter</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>no entry</vocabulary>.

While this type of sign will usually say 立入禁止, you may also encounter variations such as 立ち入り禁止 or 立入り禁止.
reading_mnemonic:
The reading for 立入 is a bit strange, but it might help you to know that it can also be written 立ち入り. The 立ち is the same one you learned with 立ち飲み and the 入り is the reading you learned with 入り口. In our version of the word, the hiragana isn't visible (it's sort of pushed into the kanji), but the word is still pronounced the same way: たちいり.

And 禁止 doesn't have any weirdness going on, so at least you have that!

examples.en: This is a good blowfish restaurant, which isn't known to the public.
examples.ja: ここは、フグ料理の穴場なんですよ。

examples.en: Do you want to go to the beach on Sunday? I know a great hidden spot!
examples.ja: 日曜日、ビーチに行きませんか？いい穴場を知ってるんです！

examples.en: The restaurant called Kagaya in Shinbashi is a hidden gem among hidden gems, even in Tokyo.
examples.ja: 新橋にあるカガヤって言うお店は、東京でも穴場中の穴場だよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
Hey, this <kanji>hole</kanji> is a really nice <kanji>place</kanji>! But no one knows about it because they think it's just a hole. That makes it a <vocabulary>hidden gem</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>hidden spot</vocabulary>, and you better hope the tourists don't hear about it.

穴場 is for places that are good but relatively unknown. You can use it for any kind of location — restaurants, parks, beaches, fishing spots only the locals know, or even a hidden study spot on campus that you always have to yourself.
reading_mnemonic:
This word uses the kun'yomi reading for each kanji. You've seen both of these readings before, but here's a mnemonic in case you need it:

Your town's <vocabulary>hidden gem</vocabulary> is a place where you can <reading>baa</reading> (ば) without shame. It's this great petting zoo no one knows about yet. It's never crowded, so you can baa at the sheep as much as you like without fear of society's judgment! (What's that? You didn't come here to baa? Okay, weirdo…)

examples.en: My nostrils are too small to fit my fingers in.
examples.ja: 私の鼻の穴は小さすぎて指が入りません。

examples.en: My hamster looks adorable when eating, with its nostrils puffing up and twitching.
examples.ja: うちのハムスターは、ご飯を食べるとき、鼻の穴がふくらんでヒクヒクするのがすごくかわいいんです。

examples.en: If you make the tip of your nose smaller through plastic surgery, the shape of your nostrils becomes triangular, and the area of the nostrils visible from the front increases, which enhances the sense of having had plastic surgery.
examples.ja: 整形で鼻先を小さくすると、鼻の穴の形が三角になって、正面から見た時に見える鼻の穴のエリアが大きくなって、整形感がアップしちゃうんですよね。

meaning_mnemonic: What's your <kanji>nose</kanji>'s <kanji>hole</kanji>? How about your <vocabulary>nostril</vocabulary>?
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the readings for 鼻 and 穴. Smell that fresh air through your <vocabulary>nose hole</vocabulary>.

examples.en: Today I had conger eel tempura for lunch.
examples.ja: 今日はお昼に穴子の天ぷらを食べました。

examples.en: The flesh of anago is soft and easy to eat.
examples.ja: 穴子の身はやわらかくて、食べやすいです。

examples.en: Since it is difficult to get conger eel in America, freshwater eel is used instead.
examples.ja: アメリカでは穴子は手に入りにくいので、代わりにウナギが使われています。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>hole</kanji> <kanji>child</kanji> isn't some kind of creepy hole child (not sure how else to describe it). It's a <vocabulary>conger eel</vocabulary>, a type of tasty eel eaten in Japan. It might be easier to learn the reading first, though, and use that, because the second meaning option is <vocabulary>anago</vocabulary>, the Japanese word for it (also used in English).
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the two kun'yomi vocab readings combined. So, 穴 and 子 to combine make あなご. Just watch out for rendaku, which changes the reading of 子 from こ to ご.

examples.en: It was a great experience.
examples.ja: すごく良い経験になりました。

examples.en: You should have a lot of experience while you're young.
examples.ja: 若いうちに色々な経験をしておいた方がいいよ。

examples.en: I've never had the experience of traveling by plane.
examples.ja: 私は、飛行機で旅行をした経験がありません。

meaning_mnemonic: Through various <kanji>test</kanji>s over the <kanji>passage of time</kanji>, you have gained much <vocabulary>experience</vocabulary>. Time and testing is all it takes.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: The sin of eating my pudding without permission is serious!
examples.ja: 私のプリンを勝手に食べた罪は重いよ！

examples.en: That was meant as a small act of atonement for my crimes, at the very least.
examples.ja: それが、せめてもの罪ほろぼしのつもりだったんです。

examples.en: Making Yurichan cry like that, he's a very sinful man.
examples.ja: あのユリちゃんを泣かせるとは、アイツも罪な男だねぇ。

meaning_mnemonic: If you have <kanji>guilt</kanji> then you have committed a <vocabulary>sin</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>crime</vocabulary>. Come here and confess to Father Koichi.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: When you come to confess your <vocabulary>sin</vocabulary> to me, you start claiming it wasn't you. You say it was some other version of you! What? How could this be? Well, you say "there are <reading>two me</reading>s (つみ) out there!" One is doing the bad stuff, and the other is you, and you haven't done any sins!

examples.en: He was found guilty of illegal immigration.
examples.ja: 彼は不法滞在で有罪となりました。

examples.en: She had an alibi, but somehow she was found guilty.
examples.ja: 彼女はアリバイもあるのに、なぜか有罪とされてしまいました。

examples.en: The perpetrator admitted the crime and accepted the guilty plea.
examples.ja: 犯人は犯行を認め、有罪を受け入れました。

meaning_mnemonic: To <kanji>have</kanji> <kanji>guilt</kanji> is to be <vocabulary>guilty</vocabulary>. This can also simply mean <vocabulary>guilt</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Bullying is a crime.
examples.ja: イジメは犯罪ですよ。

examples.en: Don't Japanese schools check teachers' criminal records?
examples.ja: 日本の学校では、先生の犯罪歴をチェックしないんですか？

examples.en: Do you know what the most serious crime in Japan is?
examples.ja: 日本で一番重い犯罪は何か知っていますか？

meaning_mnemonic: You have <kanji>crime</kanji> and you have <kanji>guilt</kanji>. Sounds like you did the <vocabulary>crime</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: This chocolate smells stinky like socks.
examples.ja: このチョコレート、くつ下の臭いがする。

examples.en: Excuse my garlic breath. It smells terrible, right? I just ate ramen.
examples.ja: ニンニク臭くてごめんね。すごい臭いよね。さっきラーメン食べたんだ。

examples.en: I got a nosebleed, so I tried to stop it by sticking a fish cake stick in my nostril, but since the stick had a hole, it didn't work, and it just smelled strongly of fish cake.
examples.ja: 鼻血が出てきたので、鼻の穴にチクワをさしこんで止血しようとしたけど、チクワは穴が開いているので意味がなかった上に、めっちゃチクワ臭かったです。

meaning_mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>stinking</kanji>? It's also <vocabulary>stinking</vocabulary> (or <vocabulary>stinky</vocabulary>).
reading_mnemonic: The reading you learned with the kanji can be used here, too.

examples.en: This town wasn't damaged by the wildfire.
examples.ja: この町は、山火事の被害は受けませんでした。

examples.en: It's not right that the victim has to be the one to endure it!
examples.ja: 被害にあった方がガマンしなきゃいけないなんて、おかしいよ！

examples.en: This earthquake has caused significant damage in many places.
examples.ja: 今回の地震では、色々な場所で大きな被害が出ています。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Incur</kanji>ing <kanji>damage</kanji> creates <vocabulary>damage</vocabulary> and  <vocabulary>harm</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: We still have enough room for a few people.
examples.ja: まだ二、三人分ぐらい余裕があるよ。

examples.en: I’d love to buy a new computer and some AKB48 figures, but I can’t afford to right now.
examples.ja: 新しいパソコンとAKB48のフィギュアを買いたいが、今は余裕が無い。

examples.en: It must be a lot of pressure, but if it's Ohtani, he'll probably handle it with ease!
examples.ja: めっちゃプレッシャーだろうけど、大谷選手ならまあ余裕でしょ！

meaning_mnemonic:
When your <kanji>surplus</kanji> is <kanji>abundant</kanji>, you have <vocabulary>leeway</vocabulary> for a lot of things. You have plenty of <vocabulary>room to spare</vocabulary>.

余裕 is used to describe a state of having ample leeway for something. It means you can handle things comfortably, without feeling stressed or overwhelmed, whether it's about money, time, or just mentally.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I wish I had been born into a wealthy family too.
examples.ja: 僕も裕福な家庭に生まれたかったな。

examples.en: Coming from a wealthy family and receiving financial support for education doesn't guarantee success in exams if one lacks intelligence.
examples.ja: 実家が裕福で、教育にお金をかけてもらっていても、地頭が良くないと受験でうまくいかないこともあります。

examples.en: The target market for luxury brands isn't necessarily wealthy individuals, but rather those who want to appear affluent. So, people who flaunt brand-name items come off as a bit tacky, you know?
examples.ja: 高級ブランドのターゲットって、本当に裕福な人じゃなくて、「自分を金持ちに見せたい人」なんだよ。だからブランド物を見せびらかしてる人って、なんかちょっとダサいんだよな。

meaning_mnemonic: You have such <kanji>abundant</kanji> <kanji>luck</kanji>! If you have abundant luck, you're probably also <vocabulary>wealthy</vocabulary>, because lots of <vocabulary>wealth</vocabulary> equals lots of luck, right?
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I finally managed to finish writing my second paper!
examples.ja: やっと二本目の論文が書けました！

examples.en: Reading a thesis takes more time than reading a light novel.
examples.ja: 論文を読むのは、ラノベを読むより時間がかかります。

examples.en: What was the theme of your college graduation thesis?
examples.ja: 大学の卒業論文のテーマは何だったんですか？

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>writing</kanji> of your <kanji>theory</kanji> is usually a <vocabulary>thesis</vocabulary>. Remember how school teachers always wanted you to present theories in writing? And to make sure you have a thesis in that <vocabulary>paper</vocabulary>? I do.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: That theory sounds too unreasonable!
examples.ja: それ、ナゾ理論すぎるでしょ！

examples.en: Don't worry about it, don't worry about it. You know, it's less likely to work out the way you theorize.
examples.ja: 気にしない、気にしない。理論通りにいくことの方が少ないでしょ。

examples.en: I'm good at conveying things dramatically, but I struggle with explaining things theoretically.
examples.ja: 私、ドラマチックに伝えるのは得意なんですが、理論的に説明するのは苦手なんです。

meaning_mnemonic: You have <kanji>reason</kanji> behind your <kanji>theory</kanji>, making it a real <vocabulary>theory</vocabulary> (unlike those that don't have reason, I guess?).
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: It won't make sense if we go by that logic.
examples.ja: その論理でいくと意味が通じないよ。

examples.en: People are not often driven by logic.
examples.ja: 人は論理で動かないことの方が多いんですよ。

examples.en: Eh? Is that guy logical? To me, he looks like a person who is all cryptic.
examples.ja: えー？あの人って、論理的かな？私にはヘリクツばっかり言ってる人にしか見えないけど。

meaning_mnemonic: Using <kanji>theory</kanji> and <kanji>reason</kanji>, you are one who uses much <vocabulary>logic</vocabulary>. Imagine this type of person, I bet you know at least one.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: The meeting starts at 3:00 p.m. Japan time.
examples.ja: 会議は日本時間の午後三時からですよ。

examples.en: What? In Japan, you are not allowed to answer the phone during a meeting!?
examples.ja: え、日本では会議中に電話に出たらダメなんですか！？

examples.en: You ditched the conference to watch a serial TV drama!? What the heck!?
examples.ja: 会議をサボって連ドラを見てるとは、何事だ！

meaning_mnemonic: A place where people <kanji>meet</kanji> and do <kanji>deliberation</kanji>. Sounds boring, but also sounds like some kind of <vocabulary>meeting</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>conference</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I see no point in that argument, what is your opinion?
examples.ja: 私はその議論には意味がないと思ってるんですが、あなたはどんなご意見をお持ちですか？

examples.en: Let's all think about the topic of wheelchair users being discussed on the Internet today.
examples.ja: 今日はネットで議論されてる車イスユーザーの話題についてみんなで考えてみましょう。

examples.en: Koichi and Viet argued on what to eat for dinner.
examples.ja: コウイチとビエトは、夕飯に何を食べるかについて議論に議論を重ねました。

meaning_mnemonic: There is much <kanji>deliberation</kanji> and <kanji>theory</kanji> exchanging when you are trying to present an <vocabulary>argument</vocabulary>. Of course, it's a very nice one. Lots of thinking and stuff, you know? That's why there's deliberation and theories instead of just screaming. That kind of "argument."
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Wow, there really are some strange things out there, aren't there!
examples.ja: へー、不思議なこともあるもんだね！

examples.en: I was dancing at the convenience store and the cashier looked at me strangely.
examples.ja: コンビニでダンスしてたら、店員さんから不思議そうに見られました。

examples.en: It's not surprising at all if a big earthquake comes anytime soon, considering how frequent earthquakes have been lately.
examples.ja: いつ大きな地震が来ても全く不思議はないほど、最近は地震が多いです。

meaning_mnemonic: This is <kanji>not</kanji> what you <kanji>thought</kanji> would happen during your <kanji>deliberation</kanji>. You thought it would be very normal. Instead, it's the opposite. It's full of <vocabulary>wonder</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>mystery</vocabulary>. It's <vocabulary>marvelous</vocabulary>
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: In this community forum, direct messaging is prohibited to prevent conflicts between users.
examples.ja: このコミュニティフォーラムでは、ユーザー同士のトラブル防止のため、DMは禁止にしています。

examples.en: This sweet potato dish called daigakuimo was made with just sweet potatoes, water, honey, and mirin. It's said to be good for preventing aging.
examples.ja: この大学芋、サツマイモと水とハチミツとミリンだけで作ったんだよ。老化防止にいいんだって。

examples.en: The teacher devised a way to prevent copy-pasting and using AI.
examples.ja: その先生は、コピペとAI使用を防止するために細工をしていました。

meaning_mnemonic: To <kanji>prevent</kanji> and <kanji>stop</kanji> someone from doing something is <vocabulary>prevention</vocabulary>. It's good to have prevention instead of letting something bad happen.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I will definitely make this business a success to prevent my hometown from becoming a ghost town.
examples.ja: 地元のゴーストタウン化を防ぐためにも、ゼッタイにこのビジネスを成功させます。

examples.en: To prevent food poisoning, please make sure to thoroughly heat it in the microwave.
examples.ja: 食中毒を防ぐためにも、電子レンジでしっかり加熱するようにしてください。

examples.en: Since there's still no way to prevent getting COVID-19, for now, people are just advised to wear masks.
examples.ja: コロナにかかるのを防ぐ方法って今はまだないんで、とりあえずマスクを付けようってなってるんですよ。

meaning_mnemonic: You're doing a <kanji>prevent</kanji>ion. When you prevent something, what are you really doing? You're trying <vocabulary>to defend against</vocabulary> something from happening. That's why this verb is a little weird and means <vocabulary>to defend</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to protect against</vocabulary>. It can also be <vocabulary>to prevent</vocabulary>, too, but just make sure you're thinking of it more like you're defending something with your prevention.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You want <vocabulary>to defend against</vocabulary> the enemy? You should probably put out that <reading>fuse</reading> (ふせ) attached to that giant bomb first then.

examples.en: The only prevention for measles is vaccination.
examples.ja: はしかの予防は、ワクチンしかありません。

examples.en: If you go to that country, please make sure to take medicine to prevent malaria beforehand.
examples.ja: その国に行くなら、事前に必ずマラリア予防の薬を飲んでください。

examples.en: To prevent sunburn, sunscreen is essential.
examples.ja: 日焼けを予防するために、日焼け止めは欠かせません。

meaning_mnemonic: To <kanji>prevent</kanji> <kanji>beforehand</kanji> is still <vocabulary>prevention</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I get excited when I face difficulties in my work.
examples.ja: 私、仕事で困難に直面すると、ワクワクするんです。

examples.en: This restaurant is very popular and is known for its difficulty in making reservations.
examples.ja: このレストランはとても人気で、予約が困難なことで有名です。

examples.en: It caused me to have difficulty walking.
examples.ja: 私はそれが原因で、歩行困難になってしまいました。

meaning_mnemonic: You're <kanji>distressed</kanji> and it's <kanji>difficult</kanji>. This is quite the <vocabulary>hardship</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>difficulty</vocabulary> you're feeling.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: The article received a lot of flak for its content.
examples.ja: その記事の内容には、たくさんの非難の声が上がりました。

examples.en: I was surprised at how many people were condemning that behavior.
examples.ja: あの行動に非難の目を向ける人が多くて、ビックリしました。

examples.en: What was meant to be a minor prank ended up exposing the young man to public condemnation.
examples.ja: ちょっとしたイタズラのつもりだったのに、その若者は世間の非難にさらされることになってしまいました。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>difficult</kanji> <kanji>injustice</kanji> to take from someone is a <vocabulary>criticism</vocabulary>. Ugh, what a pain to be criticized! So difficult, and besides, it's an injustice, because I'm perfect!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Is that really so hard to do?
examples.ja: それってそんなに難しいことなの？

examples.en: That sounds a little too difficult for me, so I'm not going to do it.
examples.ja: ちょっと私には難しそうだし、やめておくよ。

examples.en: This game is too difficult to clear.
examples.ja: このゲーム、難しすぎて全然クリアできない。

meaning_mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>difficult</kanji>? It's also <vocabulary>difficult</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: It's awfully difficult to load a cow into your <reading>Moo-zooka</reading> (むずか). Click. Boom!

examples.en: There have been a lot of earthquakes lately, haven't there? Yesterday too, right?
examples.ja: 最近、地震、多いよね。昨日もでしょ？

examples.en: Do you think man-made earthquakes really exist?
examples.ja: 人工地震って、本当にあると思いますか？

examples.en: The Great East Japan Earthquake was a massive magnitude 9.0 earthquake.
examples.ja: 東日本大震災では、マグニチュード9の大地震が起こりました。

meaning_mnemonic: An <kanji>earth</kanji> <kanji>earthquake</kanji> is just another way to say <vocabulary>earthquake</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Notice that 地 is read as じ instead of ち. You've seen this happen a few times before, so just try to remember that this is the case here.

examples.en: What’s the difference between the magnitude and seismic scale?
examples.ja: マグニチュードと震度って、何がちがうの？

examples.en: I heard that the maximum intensity of that earthquake was over seven.
examples.ja: あの地震では、最大震度が７強もあったらしいよ。

examples.en: My fish don't even twitch when the earthquake is about a three on the Japanese seismic scale.
examples.ja: うちの魚は震度３くらいの地震だと、ピクリとも動きません。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>earthquake</kanji> <kanji>degree</kanji>s is how you measure an earthquake. The 震度 is the <vocabulary>earthquake intensity</vocabulary>, AKA <vocabulary>earthquake magnitude</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>seismic intensity</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>seismic scale</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: There are still aftershocks, so please be careful.
examples.ja: まだ余震が続いているので、気をつけてください。

examples.en: How many aftershocks have you felt today?
examples.ja: 今日は何回ぐらい余震を感じましたか？

examples.en: The earthquake was followed by aftershocks.
examples.ja: その地震の後に、余震が相次ぎました。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>surplus</kanji> (that's an extra!) <kanji>earthquake</kanji> is a quake that  comes after the main (non-surplus) quake. That's an <vocabulary>aftershock</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: My major is cultural anthropology.
examples.ja: 私の専門は文化人類学です。

examples.en: My father teaches anthropology at the university.
examples.ja: 私の父は、大学で人類学を教えています。

examples.en: I’ve heard that the person who wrote this book was a Mongolian who had studied anthropology in Japan.
examples.ja: この本を書いたのは日本で人類学を学んだモンゴル人の方だそうです。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>study</kanji> of <kanji>mankind</kanji> (人類) is known as <vocabulary>anthropology</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Be careful because oil might splatter from the frying pan!
examples.ja: フライパンから油が飛ぶかもしれないので気をつけてね！

examples.en: When I arrived at the park, I saw many bubbles flying around.
examples.ja: 公園につくと、たくさんのシャボン玉が飛んでいました。

examples.en: Annual subscriptions for WaniKani are flying off the shelves.
examples.ja: ワニカニの年間サブスクリプションは、飛ぶように売れています。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>fly</kanji>, and the verb vocab version is also <vocabulary>to fly</vocabulary>. In addition to flying, the verb also means <vocabulary>to jump</vocabulary>. Just think of jumping as being some sort of... smaller version of flying, and this'll make sense.
reading_mnemonic: When you try <vocabulary>to fly</vocabulary>, the main thing holding you back is your <reading>toe</reading> (と). It's like forty pounds and holds you down.

examples.en: When you get home, wash your hands and gargle first.
examples.ja: 家に帰ったら、まず手洗いうがいをしましょう。

examples.en: This mask can be used again if you hand wash it.
examples.ja: このマスクは、手洗いすればまた使えますよ。

examples.en: Always wash your hands before cooking, of course, but be sure to wash your hands frequently during cooking as well, especially if you happen to touch meat or eggs.
examples.ja: 料理をする前には必ず手洗いするのはもちろんですが、料理中もお肉やタマゴにタッチしちゃったりしたら、小まめに手洗いするようにしてくださいね。

meaning_mnemonic: You remember how 洗う is "to wash"? Well, when you <kanji>wash</kanji> your <kanji>hand</kanji>s you're doing <vocabulary>hand washing</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The readings are the vocab readings 手 and 洗う put together.

examples.en: Eating pork cutlet curry for breakfast gives me heartburn!
examples.ja: 朝からカツカレーなんて、胸焼けするわ！

examples.en: Be careful not to drink too much coffee as it can cause heartburn.
examples.ja: コーヒーの飲みすぎは胸焼けを引き起こすことがあるので注意してください。

examples.en: I often get heartburn or burp a lot after eating convenience store onigiri. I wonder if it's because of the preservatives.
examples.ja: 俺、コンビニのおにぎりを食べると、ゲップが出たり胸焼けしたりすることが多いんです。保存料のせいなのかな。

meaning_mnemonic: When your <kanji>chest</kanji> is <kanji>burn</kanji>ing, you have what's known as <vocabulary>heartburn</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The readings are the kun'yomi vocab readings (hint is that there's hiragana sticking out there). So, just make sure you know the word 胸 and 焼く. If you do, you can combine that knowledge into this word, and hopefully not get any heartburn in the process.

examples.en: Nowadays, the Internet and the real world have become almost inseparable, haven't they?
examples.ja: 今って、ネットとリアルはほぼ不可分になってしまっていますよね？

examples.en: Honestly, the use of AI has become inseparable from my life.
examples.ja: 正直、AIの使用は、もはや自身の生活と不可分になっています。

examples.en: As you know, in WaniKani, the alligator and crab are inseparable.
examples.ja: ご存知のように、ワニカニではワニとカニは不可分です。

meaning_mnemonic:
When it's <kanji>not</kanji> <kanji>possible</kanji> to <kanji>divide</kanji> something, that makes it <vocabulary>indivisible</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>inseparable</vocabulary>.

不可分 is a formal term describing something that is inherently linked and can't be separated without losing its meaning or function.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I think the possibility of a war breaking out is low, but I'm worried.
examples.ja: 戦争になる可能性は低いと思うけど、心配だよね。

examples.en: It seems like the likelihood of it snowing on Christmas Day is very high.
examples.ja: 今年のクリスマスは雪になる可能性が高いみたいです。

examples.en: That project feels like a bundle of possibilities, doesn't it? Of course, there's also the possibility of failure, but it sounds intriguing!
examples.ja: そのプロジェクト、可能性のかたまりって感じだね。もちろん失敗する可能性もあるけど、面白そう！

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>possible</kanji> (可能) range of <kanji>gender</kanji> extends beyond two options. It means there's a <vocabulary>possibility</vocabulary> to identify with many different gender identities.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to be able to read 可能 as well.

examples.en: Please teach me how to differentiate between on'yomi and kun'yomi.
examples.ja: 漢字の音訓の見分け方を教えてください。

examples.en: This is a Chinese and Japanese reading chart of commonly used kanji.
examples.ja: これは常用漢字の音訓表です。

examples.en: In kanji, there are many exceptions to both on'yomi and kun'yomi readings, and many characters have multiple readings. Is it really necessary to memorize which readings are on'yomi and which are kun'yomi for each character?
examples.ja: 漢字の音訓って、例外も多いし、それぞれ二つ以上あるものもあるし、いちいちどれが音読みでどれが訓読みなのかを覚える必要ってあるんですかね？

meaning_mnemonic: You've seen (hopefully) 音読み and 訓読み. This is a combination of the two. This is <vocabulary>on'yomi and kun'yomi</vocabulary>, aka the <vocabulary>Chinese and Japanese readings</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: The people who live in my neighborhood are all big fans of parties.
examples.ja: 私の近所に住む人達は、パーティが大好きな人達ばかりです。

examples.en: Various people have said that people doing WaniKani quickly memorize kanji.
examples.ja: 「ワニカニをしている人達は、漢字をすぐに覚えてしまう」と色んな人達が言っていました。

examples.en: Some people laugh at the fact that my father is a pizza delivery person, but I believe those people are the ones who should be laughed at.
examples.ja: お父さんがピザの配達人であることを笑う人達もいますが、僕はそういう人達こそ笑われるべきだと思っています。

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji 達 pluralizes things sometimes. So, when you have a <kanji>plural</kanji> amount of a <kanji>person</kanji> you have more than one person, you have <vocabulary>people</vocabulary>.

Take note! When using this word, you want to attach it to the type of "people" you are talking about. For example, あの人達 (those people over there). Other examples: 男の人達, その人達, 向こうの人達, etc. You don't use this by itself, instead you use it with something describing what kind of people you're talking about.
reading_mnemonic: The readings are both kun'yomi readings of the kanji. The readings come from the word 人 and the だち of 友達, though now it's たち because it hasn't been rendaku'd. You like to <reading>touch</reading> (たち) people, you perv.

examples.en: During my trip to Kyoto, at a small restaurant I visited, I enjoyed grilled ayu fish while overlooking a calmly flowing stream.
examples.ja: 京都旅行で行った小料理屋では、静々と流れる小川を見下ろしながら、アユの塩焼きをいただきました。

examples.en: Watching the snow silently pile up, I felt like having hot cocoa.
examples.ja: 雪が静々とつもりゆくのを見て、ホットココアが飲みたくなりました。

examples.en: In old Japan, a wife who walked quietly behind her husband was considered a good wife.
examples.ja: 昔の日本では、夫の後ろを静々と歩くような妻が良妻とされてきました。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Quiet</kanji> <kanji>quiet</kanji>! Do it <vocabulary>quietly</vocabulary>, please.
reading_mnemonic: You know how 静か is しずか? Well, this is the same reading as that. Say it in a whisper with me: "<reading>しずしず</reading>." Shhh!

examples.en: I was just saying my opinion, but my boss yelled, "don’t complain," at me.
examples.ja: 意見を言っただけなのに、上司に「文句するな」と怒鳴られました。

meaning_mnemonic: You know how 文句 is a <vocabulary>complaint</vocabulary>, right? Well, add する to make it a verb and you have <vocabulary>to complain</vocabulary>. This is a really casual way to complain though, usually used in manga or on social media. Keep your eye out for it!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I never expected my house to burn down in a fire.
examples.ja: まさか火事で家が焼けるとは思っても見ませんでした。

examples.en: This bread is toasted well.
examples.ja: このパンはこんがりとよく焼けています。

examples.en: "This meat is thick, so I think it'll be a while until it's cooked." "I think it'll cook while you're doing the dishes."
examples.ja: 「この肉は厚いから、焼けるまでに時間がかかりそうだね」「あなたが皿洗いをしている間に、焼けると思うけど」

meaning_mnemonic:
Remember how 焼く is "to bake," "to burn something," or "to grill"? 焼ける is just the intransitive version. That means no direct object needed! So this verb means <vocabulary>to get baked</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to get burned</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to get grilled</vocabulary>. 

焼ける is used when something is heated and transformed by the heat. Depending on the context, it can refer to anything from a muffin getting baked, fish being grilled, or pottery being fired. You can even use it when your skin gets a tan or a house burns down. Well, that last one is kinda sad. I hope it never happens.

You can distinguish 焼ける from 焼く because when cooking, you always <reading>care</reading> (ける) to ensure the food gets baked or grilled really well. You want to make sure it's properly 焼ける'd (heated through) to be safe!
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as 焼く, so just use that knowledge and apply it here to be able to read this too.

examples.en: No electronic devices are allowed in this room.
examples.ja: この部屋への電子機器持ち込みは禁止されています。

examples.en: In this factory, workers manually check each electronic device one by one at the end of the process to make sure there are no problems.
examples.ja: この工場では、電子機器に問題がないか、最後に作業員が一つずつ手作業でチェックしています。

examples.en: I can smell electricity, you know. Young people these days are constantly using electronic devices, so I often smell electricity around them.
examples.ja: 私、電気のニオイが分かるんですよね。最近若い方は電子機器を常に使っているので、電気のニオイがプンプンします。

meaning_mnemonic:
You have an <kanji>electronic</kanji> (電子) <kanji>container</kanji> <kanji>machine</kanji>. This is just a machine that contains electricity and electric parts. So basically, an <vocabulary>electronic device</vocabulary>, or more generally, <vocabulary>electronic equipment</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>electronics</vocabulary>.

電子機器 refers to complex electronic devices like computers, smartphones, medical devices, control systems, and more. So while it can be used to refer to a wide range of electronic devices, it's usually not used for things like simple household appliances like toasters or kettles.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Oh, are we going to be sticking these fruits on skewers?
examples.ja: え、このフルーツをクシに刺すんですか？

examples.en: I've been stung by a black hornet before.
examples.ja: 黒いスズメバチに刺されたことがあります。

examples.en: I finished off a fly with a fork.
examples.ja: フォークでハエにトドメを刺しました。

meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.

The kanji itself means <kanji>stab</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to stab something</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to pierce something</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to sting something</vocabulary>.

This is a transitive verb, meaning that you're the one doing the stabbing... Should I be afraid of you?
reading_mnemonic:
Since this vocab word is made up of a single kanji, it uses the kun'yomi reading. Luckily you learned that reading with the kanji! Still, here's a mnemonic just in case:

If you're going <vocabulary>to stab something</vocabulary>, use a <reading>saw</reading> (さ). It may seem more difficult to stab something with a saw at first, but when you see the damage, plus how hard it is to get back out, you'll realize saws are the ideal stabbing tool.

examples.en: Be sure to check the route to your destination in advance using Google Maps!
examples.ja: 事前にGoogleマップで目的地までの経路をチェックしておいてくださいね！

examples.en: I wonder how these small incidents make their way into the news.
examples.ja: こういう小さい事件って、どういう経路でニュースになるんだろうね。

examples.en: The route through which the culprit obtained this drug is still unknown.
examples.ja: 犯人がこのドラッグを入手した経路はまだ分かっていません。
