meaning_mnemonic: If you <kanji>pass through</kanji> the <kanji>road</kanji>s, you are figuring out which roads to use, when to use them, and essentially coming up with the <vocabulary>route</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>course</vocabulary> to take to get to wherever you're going.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: How do you close a browser on a smartphone?
examples.ja: スマホでブラウザってどうやって閉じるんですか？

examples.en: Whoops! I closed the book before putting in the bookmark.
examples.ja: あ！シオリをはさむ前にページを閉じちゃった。

examples.en: The computer screen suddenly closed on its own.
examples.ja: 急にパソコンの画面が勝手に閉じちゃったんです。

meaning_mnemonic:
Another verb version of the kanji 閉! This is a special one that can be either transitive or intransitive, so 閉じる means <vocabulary>to close something</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to close</vocabulary>.

閉じる is for returning things that have expanded open back to their closed state. It's used for books, umbrellas, web browsers, and even eyes and mouths. There are some overlaps with 閉める (you can 閉じる or 閉める a gate, for example) but 閉める is mostly used for things like doors, windows, and curtains.
reading_mnemonic:
The reading is different from 閉める or 閉まる. Instead, 閉じる is read とじる.

Why? Because <vocabulary>to close something</vocabulary> that's expanded or spread open, you always use your <reading>toe</reading> (と)! It's easy enough with books, but umbrellas are a real challenge… But you, you can do it! You have the toe-tal control and can close anything expanded to the way it was before.

examples.en: He strives to write clear and understandable text for readers.
examples.ja: 彼は、読者にとって分かりやすい文章を書くことに心がけています。

examples.en: She loves reading letters and comments from readers.
examples.ja: 彼女は読者からの手紙やコメントを読むのが大好きです。

examples.en: Are you a reader of Tofugu's articles? Oh, you're not familiar with Tofugu? It's a website that provides easy-to-understand articles about Japanese language and culture! They have many helpful articles, so please consider becoming a reader!
examples.ja: あなたはトーフグの記事の読者ですか？え、トーフグを知らないんですか？日本語や日本文化について、分かりやすく記事にしているサイトですよ！役立つ記事ばかりなんで、ぜひ読者になってください！

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>read</kanji>ing <kanji>someone</kanji> is someone who is reading. They are the <vocabulary>reader</vocabulary> (of a book, blog, article, etc).
reading_mnemonic: The reading for 読 is the on'yomi reading, which you didn't learn with the kanji. This reading is どく, and you can remember it by thinking about how you are the <vocabulary>reader</vocabulary>, and as the reader you choose where to read. For you, the best place to read is a peaceful <reading>dock</reading> (どく). Sit on the dock and relax. Be the reader.

examples.en: I became friends with an American who was residing in Japan.
examples.ja: 日本在留のアメリカ人と友達になりました。

examples.en: Yesterday, I received my visa and residence card.
examples.ja: 昨日、ビザと在留カードを受け取りました。

examples.en: It seems that the maximum duration of stay for foreign workers engaged in household chores will be extended from five years to seven years.
examples.ja: 家事代行を行う外国人労働者の在留期間が、最長5年から7年に変わるそうです。

meaning_mnemonic:
Where you <kanji>exist</kanji> is the place you're <kanji>detain</kanji>ed. As long as you're in this place, this will be your <vocabulary>residence</vocabulary>, even if you're <vocabulary>staying in a foreign country</vocabulary>.

在留 is an official term used for people residing in a foreign country. You'll find it in phrases like 在留カード (residence card) or 在留外国人 (foreign resident).
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Our president has two jets.
examples.ja: うちの社長はジェット機を二機持っています。

examples.en: It might not be the right time yet.
examples.ja: 今はまだ、機じゃないのかもしれません。

examples.en: We are currently still waiting for the right opportunity.
examples.ja: 今はまだ、機をうかがっているところです。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

examples.en: Vampires can control the human mind at will.
examples.ja: ヴァンパイアは人の心を自在にコントロールすることができる。

examples.en: She uses her smartphone as freely as if it were a part of her body.
examples.ja: 彼女はスマホを、まるで体の一部のように自由自在に使いこなします。

examples.en: That singer has the ability to effortlessly manipulate various vocal tones, ranging from powerful high notes to soft low notes.
examples.ja: その歌手は、パワフルな高音からソフトな低音まで、様々な歌声を自在にあやつることができます。

meaning_mnemonic:
When you're all by yourself and only your <kanji>self</kanji> <kanji>exist</kanji>s, you probably have <vocabulary>full control</vocabulary>. You can do whatever you want <vocabulary>freely</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>at will</vocabulary>.

自在 is commonly used with the particle に to form the adverb 自在に. This describes how someone can handle something effortlessly, as if they have full control over it.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: The Diet has already come to a decision.
examples.ja: もう議会で決定したことなんだ。

examples.en: The opinion letter we submitted was passed by the Assembly.
examples.ja: 私たちの出した意見書が、議会で可決されました。

examples.en: Due to many lawmakers dozing off, members of the parliament have decided to stand and debate instead of sitting during sessions.
examples.ja: ウトウトする議員が多いので、議員たちは議会ではイスに座らず、立って議論することになりました。

meaning_mnemonic: The place you <kanji>meet</kanji> for <kanji>deliberation</kanji> in Japan is called the <vocabulary>Diet</vocabulary>. It's their version of <vocabulary>congress</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: The conference room is located on the third floor.
examples.ja: 会議室は三階にあります。

examples.en: This meeting room has a projector and whiteboard.
examples.ja: この会議室にはプロジェクターとホワイトボードがあります。

examples.en: Viet and Koichi went in the meeting room and still haven't come out.
examples.ja: ビエトとコウイチが会議室に入ったまんまずっと出てこないんだ。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>room</kanji> where you <kanji>meet</kanji> for <kanji>discussion</kanji>s is known as a <vocabulary>conference room</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: He is a member of parliament.
examples.ja: 彼は国会議員です。

examples.en: I lost my Diet member badge.
examples.ja: 議員バッヂを失くしてしまいました。

examples.en: When I was a college student, I was interning for a city council Diet member. It was a very good experience.
examples.ja: 大学生の時にある市議会議員のところでインターンをしていました。とてもいい経験でした。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>discussion</kanji> <kanji>member</kanji> talks about all the really important things that need to be discussed for the sake of the country. They are a <vocabulary>member of the Diet</vocabulary>. The Diet is Japan's version of congress. <vocabulary>Diet members</vocabulary> discuss really important matters.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: This turtle has a spiky tail; it looks so cool!
examples.ja: このカメ、尾がトゲトゲしててカッコいい！

examples.en: My special skill is being able to identify the type of fish just by looking at its tail.
examples.ja: 私の特技は、魚の尾を見ただけで魚の種類を当てることです。

examples.en: I'm still hung up on my friend saying, "Isn't your bird's tail short?"
examples.ja: 友達に「お前の鳥の尾、短くない？」って言われたこと、まだ尾を引いてるんですよね。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet though, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You look down and you've sprouted a <vocabulary>tail</vocabulary>! You're so shocked that all you can say is "<reading>Oh</reading>. (お) Oh okay..." This your life now. A life with a tail.

examples.en: The end of the line is here.
examples.ja: 列の最後尾はこちらです。

examples.en: To my surprise, the section chief was at the end of the line at a ramen shop I passed yesterday.
examples.ja: なんと、昨日通りかかったラーメン屋の行列の最後尾に課長がいたんだよ。

examples.en: To buy a super popular game on its release day, I went to the store before they opened, but there was already a line out front that stretched about 200 meters to the end.
examples.ja: 大人気のゲームを発売日に買うために開店前にお店に行ったけど、すでにお店の前から列の最後尾まで200mぐらいあった。

meaning_mnemonic:
You have 最, which means <kanji>most</kanji>, and 後尾, which means something like "back" or "rear" (<kanji>behind</kanji> + <kanji>tail</kanji>). When you're at the most back part of something, you might find yourself at the <vocabulary>end of a line</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>end of a queue</vocabulary>.

最後尾 is often seen on signs at the end of a long line to help people locate where to join the queue.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. Be careful, because this is 最 + 後尾, and not 最後 + 尾, meaning that 後 is read こう, not ご! You learned the こう reading with the kanji, but this might be your first time seeing it in a word, so here's a mnemonic to help you out:

Who's always waiting at the <vocabulary>end of a line</vocabulary>? It's <reading>こう</reading>いち. The dude is always the last one to get to places, and he lines up after literally everybody else, which is why he's at the end of the queue. In middle school the bullies called him "End of the Queue こういち." Poor guy.

examples.en: The weather forecast said it would rain this afternoon.
examples.ja: 天気予報では午後から雨になってたよ。

examples.en: The weather forecast was crazy off, huh?
examples.ja: 天気予報、見事に外れましたね。

examples.en: I just felt that it was troublesome to check the weather forecast beforehand.
examples.ja: 天気予報を事前にチェックするのが面倒臭かったんです。

meaning_mnemonic: This is a combination of the words 天気, meaning "weather," and 予報 meaning "forecast." Put them together and you get the <vocabulary>weather forecast</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: She looked at me with disgust, as usual.
examples.ja: 彼女はいつも通り、私に嫌悪の目を向けてきた。

examples.en: Dracula has an aversion to garlic.
examples.ja: ドラキュラはニンニクを嫌悪しています。

examples.en: Of course I felt disgusted, but I could not say anything at the time.
examples.ja: もちろん嫌悪感を感じましたが、その時は何も言えませんでした。

meaning_mnemonic: You <kanji>dislike</kanji> someone so <kanji>bad</kanji>ly that it turns to <vocabulary>disgust</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>hate</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 悪 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

When you feel <vocabulary>disgust</vocabulary> for someone all you can manage to say when you see them is, "<reading>Oh</reading>... (お), it's you." Feel the anger when you see their face, "Oh, you again. Bleh."

examples.en: Mr. Chairman, what is today's agenda?
examples.ja: 議長、今日の議題は何ですか？

examples.en: That chairman always listens to everyone's opinions fairly.
examples.ja: その議長は、いつも皆の意見を公平に聞いてくれます。

examples.en: I am just now watching the video of Chairman Powell's press conference at the first FOMC meeting of 2024.
examples.ja: 今、2024年の最初のFOMCでのパウエル議長の会見のビデオを見ているところです。

meaning_mnemonic: The person in charge of <kanji>long</kanji> <kanji>discussion</kanji>s is the <vocabulary>chairman</vocabulary>, or the <vocabulary>speaker</vocabulary>. They also say who gets to talk and for how long.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Next month, our high school's vocal music club will participate in the city's vocal ensemble contest in the high school division.
examples.ja: 来月、うちの高校の声楽部が、市の声楽アンサンブルコンテストの高等学校部門に出場することになりました。

examples.en: In America, the high school enrollment rate is high, with almost all students graduating from high school. What is the high school enrollment rate like in Japan?
examples.ja: アメリカでは、高等学校への進学率は高く、ほぼ全ての学生が高校を卒業します。日本の高等学校への進学率はどれくらいですか？

examples.en: If a foreigner wishes to enroll in a Japanese high school for study abroad, they need to be twenty years old or younger and to have received at least one year of Japanese language education at an educational institution, or to have been educated in Japanese for at least one year.
examples.ja: 外国人が留学で日本の高等学校に入学する場合、20才以下かつ教育機関において1年以上の日本語教育、もしくは日本語による教育を受けている必要があります。

meaning_mnemonic:
Remember when you learned that 高等 means "high class" and 学校 means "school?" Well put them together and you have <vocabulary>senior high school</vocabulary>! It's the most high class school you've got (unless you go to university, but that's considered to be separate). 

Fun fact: 高校 is the abbreviation of this word. Neat, right?
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Do you happen to have a throat lozenge?
examples.ja: 喉飴持ってない？

examples.en: Today, I will take water and lozenges to cure my cold, and then take it easy for the rest of the day.
examples.ja: 今日はカゼを治すために、水分とって喉飴なめて、一日ゆっくりします。

examples.en: Don't you think cough drops taste like the science room?
examples.ja: 喉飴って理科室みたいな味がすると思わない？

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Throat</kanji> <kanji>candy</kanji> is the kind of candy that should make your throat feel better. That's right, it's a <vocabulary>cough drop</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>throat lozenge</vocabulary>. Don't just eat regular candy when your throat hurts! Use the right kind.
reading_mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji. You've learned them both already, so you should be able to read this already!

examples.en: When are you expecting the baby?
examples.ja: いつ産まれる予定なの？

examples.en: It seems that puppies will be born soon at Ono-san's house.
examples.ja: 小野さんの家では、もうすぐ子犬が産まれるそうだ。

examples.en: Koichi started using WaniKani even before he was born, so by the time he was born, he could already read kanji!
examples.ja: コウイチは、産まれる前からワニカニを始めていたので、産まれた時にはすでに漢字を読むことができたんです！

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.

This is an intransitive verb. That means that it just happens, and we're not talking about what makes it happen. So this verb means <vocabulary>to be born</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading.

You know another word that means "to be born" (生まれる), and they both have the same reading!

examples.en: If you want to go to that restaurant, you can go there via Osaka or Kyoto.
examples.ja: そのお店なら、大阪経由でも京都経由でも行けますよ。

examples.en: Recently, I have been getting a little bit of work via social media.
examples.ja: 最近はSNS経由でちょこちょこお仕事をもらえるようになってきました。

examples.en: I think it's best to book your inn via the internet.
examples.ja: 旅館の予約は、インターネット経由で行うのが一番いいと思う。

meaning_mnemonic: You <kanji>pass through</kanji> somewhere for a <kanji>reason</kanji>, so you're going <vocabulary>via</vocabulary> that place.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You learned this reading for 経 with the kanji, and you learned this reading for 由 with the word 由来. If you need an extra reminder for that one, here's a mnemonic just in case:

If you're going via an unfamiliar place, I recommend you seek out a <reading>yu</reading>rt (ゆ) to stay in. Wherever it is you're going via, you can't go wrong if you stay in a yurt.

examples.en: Over there, I received sunflower seeds.
examples.ja: あそこで、ヒマワリの種をもらいました。

examples.en: When are you going to sow those seeds?
examples.ja: その種、いつまくの？

examples.en: Thanks, you've given me a good story to tell.
examples.ja: ありがとう、いい話の種ができたよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
What <kanji>kind</kanji>s of <vocabulary>seed</vocabulary>s are you going to sow? Think about all the different kinds of seeds, and the kinds of plants they'll grow into.

This can also mean <vocabulary>source</vocabulary>, as in a source of worry or joy, or even of a good story.
reading_mnemonic: Choose your <vocabulary>seed</vocabulary>s carefully, because you love to have a <reading>tan eh?</reading> (たね). You love tanning, so you don't want to plant anything that will grow tall and create shade. Choose those seed types carefully, and don't forget about your tan, eh?

examples.en: Oh, our toilet paper is almost gone.
examples.ja: あ、トイレットペーパー、もうすぐ無くなるよ。

examples.en: I've run out of things to do and I'm bored.
examples.ja: することが無くなっちゃって、ヒマなんだよね。

examples.en: Honestly, since we've become a card-centric society, the need to carry cash has become almost obsolete, hasn't it?
examples.ja: 正直、カード社会になってから、キャッシュを持つ必要性ってほぼ無くなったよね。

meaning_mnemonic:
Here we have <kanji>nothing</kanji>, followed by the verb なる. A verb that means "become nothing"? That'll be <vocabulary>to be gone</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to run out</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to be lost</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to disappear</vocabulary>.

This can be translated in various ways depending on the situation, but just remember that it always refers to something changing from being there, to not being there.
reading_mnemonic: This uses the kun'yomi reading, which you learned with 無し, so you should be good to go.

examples.en: After how many dates do you usually hold hands?
examples.ja: いつも何回目のデートで手を繋ぐ？

examples.en: Music connects people.
examples.ja: 音楽は人と人を繋ぎます。

examples.en: Nowadays, even without cables, you can connect your computer and digital camera using Wi-Fi.
examples.ja: 今はケーブルがなくてもWi-Fiでパソコンとデジカメを繋ぐことができます。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>connect</kanji>, and this verb means <vocabulary>to connect something</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to tie something to</vocabulary> something else. Like connect people, hold hands, connect a cable to a charger, etc.

Figuratively, when you want to connect something over time, like a conversation, then you want <vocabulary>to maintain</vocabulary> something over time as well.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading, which you already know from the kanji.

examples.en: I can't believe this love has come to fruition!
examples.ja: まさか、この恋が実るなんて！

examples.en: A lot of oranges have ripened again this year.
examples.ja: 今年もたくさんのオレンジが実りました。

examples.en: Teacher, your many years of effort have finally paid off!
examples.ja: 先生、長年の努力が実りましたね！

meaning_mnemonic:
You might remember 実 means "truth," but it can also mean <kanji>fruit</kanji>! That's why this verb vocab version means <vocabulary>to bear fruit</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to come to fruition</vocabulary>. 

実る literally means <vocabulary>to ripen</vocabulary>, but it's mostly used figuratively to describe when hard work leads to results, like in the phrase 努力が実る (effort pays off).
reading_mnemonic:
This is a verb, so it uses the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you out:

Your experiments have finally started <vocabulary>to bear fruit</vocabulary>. You've fully turned yourself into a <reading>mino</reading>taur (みの)! Your long-term ambitions of turning yourself into a minotaur are finally beginning <vocabulary>to come to fruition</vocabulary>. All hail our new minotaur overlord!
